abstracts.cdata!:
In spite of the partial cancellation of
            the loan, the project achieved its principal components in
            terms of value; overall the project outcome is rated as
            satisfactory. The principal achievement of this project is
            that there are now modern container terminals at the two
            principal general cargo ports of Chile. Project
            sustainability in improving port efficiency and inland
            terminals is likely while progress in improving road
            accesses is less clear. Both World Bank and Borrower
            performance are considered satisfactory. Key lessons learned
            include: The original project may have been over-designed
            and overly optimistic in setting a long and demanding
            schedule of conditions to be accomplished by the borrower in
            a short span of time. The project design over-estimated the
            effect of one relatively small loan on the pace of
            institutional change within the sector. Where there are two
            or more ministries directly involved with different aspects
            of the project, there are special considerations of project
            ownership and control. A port project can include policy
            objectives and the preparation of port-related investments,
            but responsibility for their financing and implementation
            should be assigned to the agencies concerned. Preparing the
            training component required better coordination with other
            training programs. Although the loan was cancelled, the
            continuance of Bank supervision enabled the directorate of
            public works to advance its program and benefit the port sub-sector.

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the project are
            to: (a) ensure the provision of port facilities at San
            Vicente, San Antonio and Valparaiso; (b) increase efficiency
            in port activities; (c) strengthen the institutional set-up
            of the infrastructure sector; and (d) ensure the provision
            of other high priority port-related investments.  The
            project includes two components. Part A includes (a)
            reconstruction of earthquake-damaged container and general
            cargo berths at San Antonio and Valparaiso, and remodelling
            and expanding related backup areas; (b) construction of a
            new berth at the highly congested port of San Vicente; (c)
            rehabilitation of the Baron berth at Valparaiso; (d)
            technical assistance for institutional, engineering and
            other project-related studies; and (e) training.  Part B
            components comprise construction of fishing jetties, port
            access facilities, and construction of inland terminals.
            The project brings no adverse environmental impact and will
            have aseismic design to prevent earthquake damage.
